author: Ava Meggle
title: Results day: what to do on a UK gap year
text: As we approach A-level Results Day , it's easy to think that all school leavers will have their next steps planned out. But while many will be heading off to university, it may not be the right route for everyone. While some people will have always known that their goal was to study medicine, others may not feel ready to dive into higher education , even if they have a vague idea of their aspirations. It is easy for the system to overlook those young people who don't have 'a plan'. I wonder how many students enrol on a university degree only to realise later that their real passions lie elsewhere? Whether you’re about to get your A-levels results or you have just graduated, if you’re feeling a little bit lost, you have no reason to worry. Not everyone is going to know exactly what they want from life at the age of 18. So no, you are not alone. And yes, there is a solution. While taking time to think about your passions, future prospects, and life expectations, a gap year is also the perfect opportunity to learn about yourself and get a taste of professional life. We are not talking about your stereotypical 'gap yah'. A gap year does not necessarily mean road tripping around South East Asia, reconstructing villages in Nepal, or planting trees in the Amazon. If you don't fancy leaving the country, or if a lack of money is holding you back, a gap year in the UK – or your home country – is a good option. Not only could it help with your confidence, but it could also give you valuable workplace skills. Sarah was 17 when she passed her Abitur (German equivalent of A-levels). She says: "At that time, I had no idea what I wanted to do, so I decided to take a gap year. I decided to fly to Colombia to help disabled children. But three weeks before my departure, I was informed that my application had been cancelled." Deciding to stay in her home town, Sarah found similar work at a charity in less than a week. She says: "I don’t regret a day of it; and besides, I don't think I was ready to travel so far away." A volunteer at an elderly care home. Picture: ALAMY Whether you want to volunteer, work for a multinational firm or in a local industry, the possibilities in the UK are endless. Nathaniel studies at University College London (UCL). He decided to take a gap year after his A-levels and explains: “I chose to work instead of starting university because I felt like social and professional experiences were extremely important.” He ended up staying in London, where he took two different part-time jobs, at a primary school and a marketing firm. “In the end, it didn’t just teach me technical skills ,” he says, “it also made me realise what makes a team work efficiently. But above all, I learned the basic rules that exist in any professional environment." Sarah now studies at Sciences Po in France, and believes that work placements give students the real-world skills missed at school. “I noticed that, among my classmates, those who did an internship or had a job before starting university tended to be considerably more mature," she says. "I think that my commitment made me a very attractive candidate [when I applied]. Without it, I’m not sure that I would have been chosen, as my grades weren’t amazing.” Here's what you can do on a UK gap year Whether you want to volunteer or get a work placement, Do It Trust is a platform that will find the most suitable role for you in locations across the UK. You just have to search according to your interests (education, environmental, crisis and poverty, health and social care, among others). You are then able to refine your search according to what you want to do (practical, professional, support, technology, etc) and your location. Then all you have to do is apply. Another very useful website is NCVO , which gives you the steps to take to find a volunteering project in the UK. Here are a few other websites to guide you in your research: A. If you want to support people B. If you care about the environment C. If you are a postgraduate and want to learn differently D. If you still want to explore A. If you want to support people • Volunteering Matters is a website designed to support people with disabilities or mental health issues • Shaw Trust will allow you to help disabled or disadvantaged people to find and sustain employment, or be more independent • Barnardo's will let you help vulnerable children B. If you care about the environment • Environment Job bases your search on your preferred section (climate, energy, conservation, water, wildlife among others) and your region • The Conservation Volunteers is a charity in Leeds that allows you to volunteer in conservation and education, as well as run training and fun events for children, teachers and families • London Wildlife Trust manages over 40 nature reserve sites across London C. If you are a postgraduate and want to learn differently There are some new and different ways of studying in the UK, such as Year Here. The programme, launched in March 2013, gives candidates the chance to develop their entrepreneurial skills without leaving the UK. D. If you still want to explore Who said the UK couldn’t be a good place to explore? Although the weather leaves something to be desired, there are many beautiful regions to discover, as well as cultural and historical places and cities to visit. And it will keep your costs down.
